question: Which team does Kelsey Haycook play for?

content.source_1:
**Breaking News: Kelsey Haycook Joins Portland Thorns FC Roster**

Portland, OR - In a move that's sending shockwaves through the National Women's Soccer League (NWSL), American association football player Kelsey Haycook has officially joined the Portland Thorns FC roster. According to sources close to the team, Haycook, a talented forward, has signed a multi-year deal with the Thorns, bolstering the team's attacking lineup. This move is seen as a significant coup for the Thorns, who are looking to build on their successful 2022 season. "We're thrilled to welcome Kelsey to the Thorns family," said Portland Thorns FC General Manager, Karina LeBlanc. "Her speed, agility, and goal-scoring ability make her a valuable asset to our team. We're confident she'll be a fan favorite at Providence Park." Haycook, who has previously played for several top-tier clubs, brings a wealth of experience to the Thorns. Her impressive stats, including 15 goals in 25 appearances last season, make her a formidable force on the pitch. "Kelsey is an exceptional player who will undoubtedly make an impact on our team," said Thorns Head Coach, Rhian Wilkinson. "Her work ethic, vision, and finishing ability will be a huge asset to our attacking unit. We're excited to see her in action." Data from the NWSL's official website confirms Haycook's transfer to the Thorns, with the league's Commissioner, Jessica Berman, stating, "We're delighted to see Kelsey join the Thorns. Her talent and dedication to the sport will undoubtedly inspire fans across the league." Haycook's move to the Thorns is seen as a strategic move by the team to strengthen their squad ahead of the upcoming season. With her addition, the Thorns are poised to make a strong push for the NWSL championship title. When asked about her decision to join the Thorns, Haycook said, "I'm honored to be a part of this incredible team. The Thorns have a rich history of success, and I'm excited to contribute to that legacy. I'm looking forward to getting to know my new teammates and working together to bring a championship to Portland." With Haycook's signing, the Thorns have sent a clear message to the rest of the NWSL: they're a force to be reckoned with.
content.source_2:
**SHOCKER IN ANN ARBOR: KELSEY HAYCOOK MAKES HISTORY BY JOINING MICHIGAN WOLVERINES BASEBALL**

In a stunning move that has left the sports world reeling, American association football player Kelsey Haycook has announced that she will be joining the Michigan Wolverines baseball team, becoming the first female player in the program's history. Haycook, a standout midfielder for the US Women's National Team, made the surprise announcement at a press conference on campus yesterday, flanked by Michigan Wolverines baseball coach, Erik Bakich, and athletic director, Warde Manuel. "I've always had a passion for baseball, and I'm thrilled to have the opportunity to pursue it at the highest level," Haycook said, beaming with excitement. "I'm looking forward to learning from the best and contributing to the team's success in any way I can." Coach Bakich praised Haycook's athleticism and work ethic, saying, "Kelsey is an exceptional athlete with a strong competitive drive. We're excited to see how her skills will translate to the diamond." According to sources close to the team, Haycook has been secretly training with the Wolverines for several weeks, impressing coaches with her quick reflexes and powerful throwing arm. "I was blown away by her velocity and accuracy," said Michigan pitcher, Tommy Henry. "She's got a cannon for an arm, and I have no doubt she'll be a game-changer for us this season." Haycook's decision to join the baseball team has sparked a heated debate about the role of women in men's sports, with many praising her courage and others expressing skepticism about her ability to compete at the highest level. "I think it's fantastic that Kelsey is pushing boundaries and challenging traditional norms," said Dr. Lisa Olson, a sports sociologist at the University of Michigan. "Her presence on the team will undoubtedly inspire young girls and women to pursue careers in sports, and that's something to be celebrated." Haycook's stats are certainly impressive: she's a two-time Olympic gold medalist and has scored 25 goals in 50 appearances for the US Women's National Team. But can she make the transition to baseball? "I'm not worried about the doubters," Haycook said with a smile. "I've always been someone who rises to a challenge, and I'm confident that my skills will translate to the baseball field."
